channel.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
channel.description:
[url='https://xbox360.gamespy.com/xbox-360/call-of-duty-6/1068537p1.html']https://xbox360.gamespy.com/xbox-360/call-of-duty-6/1068537p1.html[/url]
My nightmare is that every game will do what the article is about. :fffuuu:

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: AI13
item.description:
JohnKiller118:

You mean the one that doesn’t exist?

I am not sure what you mean, that you don’t believe that their games are becoming crappier and crappier, or that they are loosing ground in terms of players? Or are you being sarcastic? Sometimes I just cannot tell.

Stuntz:

Bungie is just ripping people off, why would they sell map packs, then later restrict certain gameplay modes that were actually enjoyable, Big team for instance, THEN give the map packs out for free with ODST? Can we get a positive reply for that?

No, but we can get a positive reply for them not charging a monthly fee above and beyond that required by Microsoft.

Read full topic

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: AI13
item.description:
JohnKiller118:

EA isn’t that bad, really. Like I said before, Madden aside, there are plenty of great games under the EA label (see: Mass Effect 2, Battlefield: Bad Company 2.)
Activision, while still publishing good games, are in a league of their own when it comes to corporate greed.

True, and with Bungie’s spiral into failure, at least they have the decency to release something somewhat new with each milking attempt.

Read full topic

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: Medevilae
item.description:
SURPLUS_NiNjA:

Not meant for those of us with taste. Valve doesn’t have much of a market in Asia it makes sense to start getting into Asian market to have a (I think) Korean developer help. Most of the FPS I have played that came from Asia where MMOFPS with micro-payment so, yeah…

Well technically it isn’t their game. They’re just licensing rights to the name for the Japanese company- but it’s VERY strange.

Read full topic

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: Surplus
item.description:
Medevilae:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Counter-Strike_Online

https://www.ebaumsworld.com/video/watch/80803546/

What. The. Fuck. (You gotta look at them both.)

Not meant for those of us with taste. Valve doesn’t have much of a market in Asia it makes sense to start getting into Asian market to have a (I think) Korean developer help. Most of the FPS I have played that came from Asia where MMOFPS with micro-payment so, yeah…

Also since most of the Korean fps I have played just rips off Western titles it makes sense for them to take a ride on the Cod Zombie train.

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: Rga_Noris
item.description:
I think we have too little information to sink this idea too quickly. We have a CEO “hinting” that CoD would go subscription based.

Now, subscription base makes sense for games like WoW or any other game where its playability would require constant monitoring/service from the developer. For wow, they need to maintain boat loads of servers and accounts, all of which cost money. You are spending your 15 bucks a month to get something.

If COD goes MMO, then this model is logical.

But an FPS? Unless this next CoD comes with massive amounts of updates, add-ons, new maps, new campaigns, and basically gives you something to pay for every month, it simply is not worth it. Simply getting the ability to play the game for the month is not worth 15 dollars, unless you only intend on playing for 4 months.

As mentioned, Valve has released FPS games that have come with constant updates and additional free content. This content is worth money, yet they give it away for free to the PC owners.

Not that I WANT to pay for Valve’s extra goodies, but lets face it: If Valve asked for a small fee for the TF2 updates (I know, they do on XBox… not their choice) it would actually be quite fair.

Oh, and Activision throwing some stupid idea around hardly comes anywhere near even possibly being the “future of gaming.” Over react much?

Read full topic

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: Kairouseki
item.description:
Well, they did remake Half-Life in the Source Engine. They just didn’t update the textures or graphics :retard: .

And I couldn’t really care less about CoD online. I don’t really think it’s all that fun and I don’t feel like throwing money at Microsoft to be able to get online…

Read full topic

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: Lord_Grievous
item.description:
I prefer Half-Life Source over HL1 any day

Especially with the HD pack.

Read full topic

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: CTID
item.description:
Well, Valve negotiated with Microsoft to keep the updates to TF2 on the 360 free, but Microsoft refused. That’s why (apparently) updates are farther between, so that they release several at once to make up for the cost.

And I don’t see why people bash so HL:S so much. It’s not like Valve said that they were going to completely redo the game in the Source engine. Like someone else here said, it was just Valve proving that it would be extremely easy to import HL’s resources onto the engine.

Read full topic

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: Stuntz
item.description:
Jeannotvb:

Valve will follow the same path over time, just wait for the original employees to leave or retire. Same thing happend to Infinity Ward.

I highly doubt that, Valve is the ONLY industry I know that does updates for there games ALOT, for FREE (Team Fortress 2 (PC only), Left 4 Dead Survival mode) Had the Orange Box which contains 5 different games, 3 of them new for the price of one. And does their own funny little videos (Team Fortress 2’s Meet The videos). The only bad thing that Valve has done so far in their career was Half-Life Source.

PLUS! They are the only ones to CARE about their customers. Gabe Newell went to a college class full of deaf students, and took some tips on what they can improve to make the game more enjoyable for them.

Read full topic

item.title: Possibly the future of gaming?
item.dc:creator: Schizophriend
item.description:
JohnKiller118:

This isn’t going to happen. About 75% of Call of Duty fans are XBox 360 owners, who have to pay for their online. Activision would be committing economic suicide if they did this.

Half the CoD fans I know would be pissed about it, but they would still fork out the cash for it. Thats what scares me.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: Jeannotvb
item.description:
Stuntz:

Its a good thing i dont play their shit, its not the future of gaming. Valve would never go that low. As sad as it may seem though, there WILL be people who will buy a subscription to play COD, them damn fanboys. Its sad that people already do it for WoW.

Valve will follow the same path over time, just wait for the original employees to leave or retire. Same thing happend to Infinity Ward.
